message.content:
<<<api>>>: StringTokenizer.nextToken
<<<code>>>: public class TestStringTokenStrict {

    static void altStringTokenizer(StringTokenizer st) {
        while (st.hasMoreTokens()) {
            st.nextToken(); //skip the first token
            String second = st.nextToken(); //get the second token
            st.nextToken(); //skip the third token
            String fourth = st.nextToken(); //get the fourth token

            System.out.println("Second: " + second + ", Fourth: " + fourth);
        }
    }

    public static void main(String[] args) {
        String input = "First\tSecond\tThird\tFourth";
        StringTokenizer st = new StringTokenizer(input, "\t");
        altStringTokenizer(st);
    }
}
<<<explanation>>>: In this code, we are using the StringTokenizer.nextToken() method to skip over and retrieve specific tokens from a string. The StringTokenizer object 'st' is created with the input string and the tab delimiter. The altStringTokenizer() method is then called with this StringTokenizer object. Inside this method, we use the nextToken() method to skip over the first and third tokens, and retrieve the second and fourth tokens. These retrieved tokens are then printed to the console. This approach avoids any redundant if checks and is efficient for processing large files.
